div1.head: Biography
div1.p: Jonah Yoder fought in the cavalry of the 16th Pennsylvania Regiment. His diary begins at camp at Potomac Roads and follows his regiment's movement throughout Northern Virginia in 1863.

div3.head: May the 10, 1863
div3.p: This day is plesant this afternoon about twoe oclock we signed the pay roll and about five oclock we got our pay paid by majerPotter.

div3.head: Monday the 11
div3.p: This day is plesant This morning I started to the one hunderd and twenty six regiment and got back this afternoon

div3.head: Tuesday the 12
div3.p: This day is plesant and I was detailed to help to dind the majers quarters

div3.head: Wednesday the 13
div3.p: This day is plesant and very warm

div3.head: Thursday the 14
div3.p: This morning is cloudy and raining this afternoon we had a thunder shower and I was detached for gaurd

div3.head: Friday the 15
div3.p: This morning is clear and Crambargrer and me started to take a walk

div3.head: Saturday the 16
div3.p: This morning is very plesant This evning there was a man buried of company L He died this morning of the tnyfuires fevar his name was Soliman Humparly

div3.head: Sunday the 17
div3.p:
This day was plesant we had preaching by the chaplain of the first Pa cavalry the Chaplain was from
Lainster County his name is hardy heabe and at four oclock there was inspection

div3.head: Monday the 18
div3.p: This day is plesant this afternoon we moved our camp about towe hundred rods from the old one into an opan feild

div3.head: Tuesday the 19
div3.p: This day is plesent and I was detailed to fix up the adjatant quarters and the balance of the day I run about

div3.head: Wednesday the 20
div3.p: This day is plesant our Leut cornal has resignd and one of our majers and, I was on gaurd

div3.head: Thursday the 21
div3.p: This day is plesant This evning I went to the railrod to help to load a cuple of wagons with grain

div3.head: Friday the 22
div3.p: This day is plesant and this morning about six oclock we left camp to go on picket and going along we pased a store, said The Parerson Store, and had our reserve close by.

div3.head: Saturday the 23
div3.p: This day is plesant This day still on picket and about 2 oclock A.M. there was ten men and sergant went out on a scout

div3.head: Sunday the 24
div3.p: This day is plesant and still on picket at nine oclock they was a 5 of us went from the main reserve and went out, out in the field to stand post and partroll we partrolled past the monture house to the log church on the opisate side of the creek and about five forks we was ordered to drag in our any go to camp we got to camp about 1 A.M.

div3.head: Monday the 25
div3.p: This day has been misting and raining all day we left about seven oclock A.M. to march we went on to the bartwood farm then we fed our horses then we went about a mile beyond the log church there we remanded for the night

div3.head: Tuesday the 26
div3.p: This morning is plesant we took up our line of march at six A.M. we marched on to belton station there we camped for the night

div3.head: Wednesday the 27
div3.p: This day is plesant we took up our line of march at five A.M.to march back to deep run we went by morisville we camped at deep run on picket about 11 oclock A.M. and there was some of us went down in spiner ford to picket

div3.head: Thursday the 28
div3.p: This is plesant and on picket and the rebels are still moving about on the of the river but how much force they have I dont know

div3.head: Friday the 29
div3.p: This day is plesant and still on picket

div3.head: Saturday the 30
div3.p: This day is plesant and this afternoon we was relieved of picket by the third Pa sy and we was ordered back to deep run

div3.head: Sunday the 31
div3.p: This morning is plesant and at five oclock we left deep run and went through morisville and went on to cattlet station and from their we went on to licking creek there we encamped then

div3.head: Monday the 1 June
div3.p: This day is plesant this afternoon we moved our camp about tane hundred yards from where we encamped the first place

div3.head: Tuesday the 2
div3.p: This day is plesant. To day williams M. Appelbaurgh was promoted to sergant major and F. Dgarmon was promoted to regimental quarter master sergant to fill M. Appelbaurgs place

div3.head: Wednesday the 3
div3.p: This day is plesant this afternoon our old horses were and saddles were condamed

div3.head: Thursday the 4
div3.p: This day is plesant This afternoon we drawed sabers.

div3.head: Friday the 5
div3.p: This day is plesant today they was a detachment to go out dismonted to sulpher springs to suport the batrey wheir the mounted men went acris the river to start out the rebels.

div3.head: Saturday the 6
div3.p: This morning is plesant and this morning we started to go along with the batery and about six oclock this evening we started to go back we came back to Fayettville there we staid there for the night

div3.head: Sunday the 7
div3.p: This morning is plesant this morning we left Fayettville for camp and got there about twelve oclock

div3.head: Monday the 8
div3.p: This morning is plesant this afternoon about three oclock we got orders to march we went as far as marisville ther we stoped for the night

div3.head: Tuesday the 9
div3.p: This morning we plesant we took up our line of march about five oclock for ladgs ford and the caverly went across our regiment stand on this side and had a small fight they was a good many wounded and our men took a great many prisoners

div3.head: Wednesday the 10
div3.p: This day is plesant this afternoon we left hely ford for the old camp we went around by bealton we got to camp about eleven oclock at night

div3.head: Thursday the 11
div3.p: This day is plesant and near noon in the old camp again at licking creek

div3.head: Friday the 12
div3.p: This day is plesant and to day our captain got his comision for leutenant cornal of our regiment and they was three cheers for him from every man in the regiment

div3.head: Saturday the 13
div3.p: This day is plesant and they was a lot of artilery and infintry went by here towards Alexandria

div3.head: Sunday the 14
div3.p: This morning we went back to warington Junction encamped for the night

div3.head: Monday the 15
div3.p: This day is plesant and we left warington Junction about towe oclock P.M. and went by callot station and bristo and thare we came on this side of manas Junction and stayed there for the night

div3.head: Tuesday the 16
div3.p: This day is plesant we are still laying about towe miles of the Junction we drawed some rations and forage

div3.head: Wednesday the 17
div3.p: This day is plesant and we took up our line of march and went on to centervill there the mounted men went of to the left and those that had bad horses that were condemed where sent on to Alexandria we went by fairfax court house and about towe mile on this side of the court we encamped for the night

div3.head: Thursday the 18
div3.p: This morning is plesant and we took up our line of march for Alexandria we got there about tane oclock we encamped on the banks of the potomac about a mile of the town and this evening we had a shower

div3.head: Friday the 19
div3.p: This day has been drisling and raining all day and we where still laying in the dismounted camp

div3.head: Saturday the 20
div3.p: This morning is plesant and they was a lot of us detached to go for horses we went to the landing and got on a boat and went across to washington to get horses but there was none there we lay there about towe houres than we came back to alexandria and drawed horses there and went back to camp and than all those that had horses started for to join the regiment we went within towe mile of fairfax there we encamped for the night

div3.head: Sunday the 21
div3.p: This day is plesant and we took up our line of march for sniders creek where our force where enjoyed we pased through alide and went through midleburg and we encamped about a mile on the other side of the town for the night

div3.head: Monday the 22
div3.p: This day is plesant this day our force fell back on this side of midleburg to take a knew position the rebels folowed them up as far as the town there they stoped

div3.head: Tuesday the 23
div3.p: This day is plesant This morning our regiment out on picket about towe mile of camp

div3.head: Wednesday the 24
div3.p: This day is plesant this morning we was releived by our first new Jersy and we went back to camp at dover mills

div3.head: Thursday the 25
div3.p: This morning we turned over our extra bagage and our shelters tents and this afternoon it comenced raining

div3.head: Friday the 26
div3.p:
This day is plesant this morning our force left dover Mills and went on to this side of the goose creek
and encamped there for to night

div3.head: Saturday the 27
div3.p: This day is clody we left goose creek at towe P.M. went on to the river edwards fery there our regiment went up towards leesburg about towe mile crossed the fery to gaurd the rear untill our train crosed over and our regiment crossed over at eight P.M. and than we drawd forage there and than we went on to barnesville and got their at six A.M. and than we stoped their to get something to eat

div3.head: Sunday the 28
div3.p:
This day is plesant and we lay at barnsville untill towe P.M. than we started and posed Aeurchdlbert mount chappell and than we pased a small villiage called fayetsville and strem
we crosed the Monaceey river and than we crosed the baltimore and ohio railroads and encamped near fredrick city for the night

div3.head: Monday the 29
div3.p: This morning it is raining and at ten A.M. we took up our march and went through the city and crosed the monnacy river and went on to new mincer and encamped their for the night

div3.head: Tuesday the 30
div3.p: This day is plesant we took up our line of march at eight A.M. and went to west minsterd there we stoped to get our diner and than we marched through the town and went on to menchester there we encamped there for the night

div3.head: July the 1
div3.p: This morning is plesant at seven a.m. we took up our line of march and went on to homors Junction where the rebels destroid some of our cars and tore up the railroad and there we got some forage for our horses and than we went on to Jeferson and from there we went on to hanover we pased through the town between twelve and one oclock and than went up for the night in a wheat field for the night

div3.head: Thursday the 2
div3.p: This day is plesant we took up our line of march seven A.M. and went on to sherlysburg and than we went to bush town and went on to about five mile fo gettesburg there we stopped to fix our diner and about three P.M. the was hevy firing in the direction of gettesburg it was continued till about eight oclock than the firing was ceased

div3.head: Friday the 3
div3.p: This day is plesant This morning the canonading was comenced again about four P.M. our squadron was deplowed as sermishers and they was very hevy firing with canon and musketry and about five oclock the firing was ceased and we was taken of the sermish about eight oclock

div3.head: Saturday the 4
div3.p: This day it is cloudy and our regiment went out on a scout and this afternoon it comenced raining and rained all day and and captured a rebel hospital with about twenty five wounded rebels and went on to huntsville and than we came back

div3.head: Sunday the 5
div3.p: This day is plesant and we went out on a picket and our regiment was with drowen about eleven oclock and than we started for chambersburg we wemt through gettysburg and over the battle ground and the dead where laying thick and than we went on to cashtown and than we went on through the gap to caldona furnace wich the rebels burned last friday and encamped there for the night

div3.head: Monday the 6
div3.p: This morning is cloudy we took up our line of march at seven A.M. we went through green wood and on to fayettsville and we went on to knew franklin there our regiment turned to come back to caletone furnace there we encamped for the night

div3.head: Tuesday the 7
div3.p: This day is plesant There was a man of comp G shot by acdent of one of comp C and we left the furnace at seven oclock we went on by greenwood and fayettsville and frankstown and pasing there there we encamped there for the night

div3.head: Wednesday the 8
div3.p: This morning it is cloudy and raining and thay was a detail made to go to pote mille for forage and than we went on to maymesburg there we joined the regiment and than they stoped to feed and than started to cross the mountain went to the top of the mountain to a place called the Vramon and than we turned to our left and went out along the mountain and encamped on the top of the mountain for the night

div3.head: Thursday the 9
div3.p:
This day is plesant This morning at seven oclock we took up our line of march and went by boosrville and Magestown there we stoped to get our diner and than we went on to midletown and encamped there for
the night in a wheat feild

div3.head: Friday the 10
div3.p: This day is plesant this morning we moved our camp about a half a mile back of town and than they was one squadron of our regiment went out on picket about towe mile south of town

div3.head: Saturday the 11
div3.p: This day is plesant this afternoon we was taken in off of picket to march to boomesboro we got there about ten oclock and encamped there

div3.head: Sunday the 12
div3.p: This morning it is plesant this afternoon we had a small thunder shower

div3.head: Monday the 13
div3.p: This morning it is cloudy and raining we moved our camp about towe mile rods from where we lay out of the mud

div3.head: Tuesday the 14
div3.p: This day is cloudy we took up our line of march at eight A.M. we pased a curch called emanuel curch and went on along the west side of the myroland highth and crosed the Potomac at harpers fery and went up along shanadoa river to the baliver hights there we encamped for the night the rebels are about eight miles of this place our men sheled them out of this place from the fortification on the maryland heights

div3.head: Wednesday the 15
div3.p: This day is plesant we took up our line of march at seven A.M. for shepards town we captured eight prisoners tue ambulance and twelve horses at shepards town and at our regiment went on beyond the town on a scout and returned to shepards town in the evening and went on picket on the left of town

div3.head: Thursday the 16
div3.p: This day is plesant This morning we was releived by the tenth knew york reg and than we went o the right of the town and stoped to get our diners and feed our horses and about the time some of us had got our diners the rebels came in contact with our picket and than we had to saddle and get out and about one oclock the batle was opened and our regiment was on the serimish line and about six oclock the firing the firing was ceased we got to men wounded one was John Bailur and serg James Ylekenady and about twelve oclock we was with drawen and started for harpersfery

div3.head: Friday the 17 1863
div3.p: This morning is cloudy and raining and we fell back to harpersfery and encamped there for the presant

div3.head: Saturday the 18
div3.p: This day is plesant we are still in camp

div3.head: Sunday the 19
div3.p: This day is plesant This morning is plesant and all those that had condemed horses started to get knew ones we crosed the river at harpersfery and went down along the to knoxville there we got the horses to us that had very bad ones we did not take many of them they were worse than the ones we had from there we went to berlin there we crosed the river and went to Powerystown there we encamped for the night

div3.head: Monday the 20, 1863
div3.p: This day is plesant we took up our line of march at seven A.M. and pased through leeysburg and went on for goose creek and encamped there for the night

div3.head: Tuesday the 21
div3.p: This day is plesant we took up our line of march at seven oclock A.M. and crosed the goose creek and went by centerville and crosed the bull run and encamped about a mile on this side of the bull run for the night

div3.head: Wednesday the 22
div3.p: This day is plesant we took up our line of march at seven A.M. and went by manass Junction and went on to bristo station and encamped there

div3.head: Thursday the 23
div3.p: This day is plesant we are still beying in camp at bristo station

div3.head: Friday the 24-1863
div3.p: This day is plesant we left bristo at seven A.M. and went along the railroad to catlet station and went on to warington Junction there our squadron went up along the warenton branch of the railroad to turky run there capt. Alexandria took a part of the squadron and want on to warenton and than we, we returned to turkey run to picket and than the fourth Pa. and staid here there untill morning

div3.head: Saturday the 25
div3.p: This day is plesant This morning we went back to warington to join the regiment and staid there untill four P.M. and than we went to bealton and encamped for the night

div3.head: Sunday the 26, 1863
div3.p: This morning is plesant this afternoon they was seven of our company went out on picket about a mile and a half from camp and was releived again in the evening by the tenth NY. and went back to camp

div3.head: Monday the 27, 1863
div3.p: Camped at bealton This day is plesant this day laying in camp there is infintry marching by here they are going to put up the railroad bridge at the rapahanock station

div3.head: Tuesday the 28
div3.p: This day is plesant our regiment is still in camp This afternoon they was fifteen prisoners brought in by the scouts nine hundred and this evening they was a heavy thunder gust

div3.head: Wednesday the 29
div3.p: This day is cloudy we left camp at ten A.M. and went towards warenton and encamped about towe of the town for the night

div3.head: Thursday the 30
div3.p: This morning at ten A.M. oclock we took up our line of march and the raphanock river at the wather bee ford and went on to aenasvile and than our regiment on towards crosrod to picket and it rained very heavy

div3.head: Friday the 31
div3.p: This morning is plesant after the rain and still laying in the reserve

div3.head: Saturday the 1 of August 1863
div3.p: This day is plesant they was three rebels came in our line to give them selfs up and than we was by the 1 maine and than we went back to anasville there we encamped

div3.head: Sunday the 2
div3.p: Camp at anasville This morning is plesant and we are still laying in camp and this evening we had dress parade and inspection of arms

div3.head: Monday the 3
div3.p: This morning is plesant today I was detailed to tend to the captain horse and pack mule

div3.head: Tuesday the 4
div3.p: This morning is cloudy and still laying in camp and they was towe squadron of our regiment went out on scout and at ten A.M. they mule train started for waranton for forage and there was a heavy Thunder shower we got to waranton at six P.M. and lay there all night

div3.head: Wednesday the 5
div3.p: This morning is plesant and about ten A.M. we pack up and started for Amosville and got there at five P.M.

div3.head: Thursday the 6
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still in camp and at ten A.M. we moved camp about a quater of a mile into a place where there is more wood and fixed up our tents

div3.head: Friday the 7 - 1863
div3.p: This morning is plesant and we received orders to pack up to march we went by Inporom and Newport within a mile of Sulpher Springs and we had a thunder shower

div3.head: Saturday the 8, 1863
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still laying in camp there was inspection

div3.head: Sunday the 9, 1863
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still laying camp and our squadron went out to escort a batery to Carnal Randolph co. head quarters

div3.head: Monday the 10, 1863
div3.p:
This morning is plesant and still laying in camp and I went out to the picket reserve with some rations
for the company and today we got our knew recrute his name is Benjiman McWilliams from monture county

div3.head: Thuesday the 11, 1863
div3.p: this morning is plesant and still laying in camp and I went out to the picket reserve with forage

div3.head: Wednesday the 12, 1863
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still laying in camp

div3.head: Thursday the 13
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still laying in camp and about ten oclock our regiment was releived and than we moved camp about a half mile and it comenced raining

div3.head: Friday the 14
div3.p: This morning is cloudy but not raining and still laying in camp

div3.head: Saturday the 15
div3.p:
This morning is plesant and we received orders to pack up to be redy to march at eight A.M. we crosed
the Raphamock river at sulpher springs and took the Warenton road and pased through Warenton and went on within a mile of catlet station and encamped there for the night

div3.head: Sunday the 16
div3.p: This morning is plesant and we cleaned of ground for to encamp upon

div3.head: Monday the 17
div3.p: This morning is plesant and our regiment was ordered out to scout all that had horses had to go

div3.head: Tuesday the 18
div3.p: This morning is plesant and our regiment returned this evening

div3.head: Wednesday the 19, 1863
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still laying in camp

div3.head: Thursday the 20
div3.p: This day is plesant still laying in camp and this afternoon the pay master came and we signed the pay rolls

div3.head: Friday the 21, 1863
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still laying in camp and to day we payed us and than our regiment went to picket at haymarket

div3.head: Saturday the 22
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still laying in camp and this afternoon I went out with the pack mule with rations

div3.head: Sunday the 23
div3.p: This morning is plesant and still laying in camp and our regiment was releived by the first maine and returned to camp

div3.head: Monday the 24
div3.p: This morning is plesant we was ordered to pack up to march at eight A.M. we went by warenton and crosed the river and went to the old camp and put up our quarters

div3.head: Thuesday the 25
div3.p: This day in the old camp again and this afternoon we had a thunder shure

div3.head: Wednesday the 26
div3.p: This day is plesant and our regiment received orders to get ready to go on a litle march they went out to amsvill there they had a small sermish with the rebils and then returned to camp

div3.head: Thursday the 27
div3.p: This day is plesant and still laying in camp and we had inspection of arms

div3.head: Friday the 28
div3.p: This morning we was ordered to pack up to go on picket we relived the first maine

div3.head: Saturday the 29
div3.p: This day is plesant and still on picket

div3.head: Sunday the 30
div3.p: This day is plesant and still on picket we was relived by the fourth Pa and returned to camp

div3.head: Monday the 31
div3.p: This day is plesant and we was mustered for two mouths pay

div3.head: September Thuesday the 1
div3.p: This day is plesant and still laying in camp at sulpher springs

div3.head: Wednesday the 2
div3.p: This day is plesant and we received orders to get ready to go on a scout we went out by amosville and than we went on to sandy hook and from there we came back by plint hill and came on to ansville there we put up for the might, took four prisoners

div3.head: Thursday the 3
div3.p: This day is plesant and we returned to camp

div3.head: Friday the 4
div3.p: This morning is plesant and at eight we left camp for picket we went out by Jiferson

div3.head: Saturday the 5
div3.p: this day is plesant and still on picket to day was four rebels came into our lines
